scenes.plot_segment: Meredith Grey narrates about the complexities of intimacy, describing it as something everyone wants but also fears, and as both difficult to live with and impossible to live without. She connects intimacy to the "three Rs": relatives, romance, and roommates. Early morning in the shared house, George O'Malley showers while Meredith and Izzie Stevens walk around in their underwear, unfazed by his discomfort. George, embarrassed, asks if Meredith is using his toothbrush, highlighting the awkwardness and tension of their living situation. The roommates banter about household responsibilities, with Izzie teasing George and Meredith warning them not to use her toothbrush.

Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, and Izzie Stevens share a cramped bathroom early in the morning. George, uncomfortable and naked in the shower, complains about Meredith and Izzie casually walking around in their underwear. Izzie teases George, telling him he needs to get used to their living habits. The conversation shifts to household responsibilities, with Izzie reminding George that they’re out of tampons. George adamantly refuses to buy “girl products,” insisting it’s not his job as a man. Meredith tries to mediate as the roommates banter about chores, boundaries, and living together, highlighting the awkward but humorous tension in their new arrangement.

Cristina Yang leads a group of interns through the hospital corridors before dawn, instructing them on the importance of bedside manner—reminding them to say please, thank you, and to apologize to patients when necessary. She warns that making their resident, Dr. Bailey, look bad will result in harsh treatment. Cristina, Meredith Grey, Izzie Stevens, George O'Malley, and Alex Karev are told to complete their pre-rounds and have their patient reports ready by 5:30 a.m., as they discuss their hopes for interesting cases that day.

In the hospital corridor early in the morning, Alex Karev greets Izzie Stevens by calling her "Dr. Model," referencing her recent appearance in a lingerie catalog, and teases Cristina Yang by calling her "Dr. Evil Spawn." The interns joke about Izzie’s modeling photos and tattoos, with Alex making snide remarks while Cristina rolls her eyes. Izzie tries to brush off the teasing but is visibly annoyed. George O'Malley joins the group, complaining about being stuck with frequent dressing changes for colostomy patients and hoping for more interesting cases. Cristina is focused on getting assigned to the Whipple procedure and is frustrated by the competition among the interns. Alex accuses George of being late and hints at rumors about George having a crush on one of his roommates, which George awkwardly denies. The conversation is filled with competitive banter and teasing as the interns head off to start their rounds.

Cristina Yang enters Elizabeth Fallon’s hospital room early in the morning, eager to review her chart. Fallon, a former scrub nurse at the hospital now admitted with suspected pancreatic cancer, immediately recognizes Cristina’s ambition and deduces she wants to scrub in on her rare Whipple procedure. Fallon calls out Cristina for her motives and insists on being addressed as Nurse Fallon, while referring to Cristina by her first name. Their exchange is direct and candid, with Fallon’s experience and insight making it clear she understands the dynamics of the interns and the surgical hierarchy.

Izzie Stevens enters Mr. Humphrey’s hospital room to perform his pre-rounds exam for an upcoming prostate biopsy. Mr. Humphrey, uncomfortable with Izzie’s presence, insists on seeing Dr. Bailey or Dr. Victor instead. He recognizes Izzie from her lingerie modeling photos recently published in a magazine, which have been circulating among the hospital staff. Agitated and embarrassed, Mr. Humphrey tells Izzie to leave, refusing to let her examine him. Izzie, taken aback but maintaining her professionalism, exits the room as Mr. Humphrey remains adamant about not wanting her involved in his care.

At the house, George O'Malley expresses discomfort about Meredith Grey and Izzie Stevens walking around in their underwear, while Izzie teases him and tells him to get used to it. The roommates bicker about household boundaries and responsibilities, with George insisting he won’t buy tampons because he’s a man. The conversation shifts when Meredith asks if George has a crush on Izzie, which he awkwardly denies, claiming he’s interested in someone else. Their discussion is interrupted by a page from Dr. Bailey, summoning George, Meredith, and Alex Karev to assist Dr. Shepherd with a trauma case at the hospital.

Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, Izzie Stevens, Alex Karev, and Derek Shepherd work together in the trauma bay to stabilize Jorge Cruz, who has seven nails embedded in his skull after falling down stairs while carrying a nail gun. Jorge is conscious but has lost his vision. With the CT scanner down due to technical issues, the team discusses alternative imaging options, deciding to use X-rays and a C-Arm to guide the removal of the nails. Meredith and George gather Jorge’s medical history, learning he has experienced headaches and dizziness for months. As they prepare for surgery, Jorge asks for his wife, Sona, who arrives and immediately scolds him for the accident. The team continues to assess Jorge’s condition and discuss the risks of bleeding and infection, coordinating their plan for the upcoming procedure.

Cristina Yang presents Elizabeth Fallon’s case to Dr. Preston Burke, highlighting Fallon’s history as a former scrub nurse at the hospital and her diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. Burke notes Cristina’s assertive approach and reveals he had planned to assign Fallon’s surgery to Meredith Grey, Ellis Grey’s daughter. Nurse Fallon, insisting on being called “Nurse Fallon,” remarks that despite working alongside Ellis for 18 years, she never met Meredith. Burke explains that Meredith is currently occupied with Jorge Cruz, the trauma patient with nail gun injuries.

Dr. Miranda Bailey instructs Alex Karev to take Nurse Elizabeth Fallon for an MRI and additional tests to assess her worsening jaundice and elevated liver enzymes. Cristina Yang is told by Dr. Bailey to stay with Nurse Fallon and closely monitor her condition. As Cristina accompanies Fallon, she tries to hide her disappointment at not being assigned to the Whipple procedure. Meanwhile, Meredith Grey, Izzie Stevens, and Cristina discuss the rarity and prestige of participating in a Whipple surgery, with Cristina expressing frustration over missing the opportunity and Meredith being chosen instead.

In the locker room at the hospital, Alex Karev questions George O'Malley about what it's like living with Meredith Grey and Izzie Stevens, specifically asking if they walk around in sexy underwear and if it feels like living with sisters. George, visibly uncomfortable, awkwardly denies that it's anything like that, insisting that he doesn't see them as sisters and that they aren't coming on to him. Alex continues to tease George, but George tries to clarify the situation, clearly embarrassed by the assumptions about his living arrangement with Meredith and Izzie.

Miranda Bailey and Izzie Stevens prepare Mr. Humphrey for his prostate biopsy. As Izzie attempts to assist, Mr. Humphrey becomes visibly uncomfortable and demands that Izzie leave the room, referencing her recent lingerie modeling photos and admitting he feels emasculated by her presence. Bailey tries to calm Mr. Humphrey and reassure him, while Izzie stands her ground, asserting her professionalism and insisting she be treated as a doctor rather than judged for her past modeling work.

Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, Izzie Stevens, Alex Karev, and Derek Shepherd work together in the ER to stabilize Jorge Cruz, who has seven nails embedded in his skull after falling down stairs with a nail gun. Jorge is conscious but blind, and the CT scanner is down, so the team opts for X-rays and a C-Arm to guide the removal of the nails. Sona Cruz, Jorge’s wife, arrives and describes Jorge’s recent symptoms—persistent headaches, dizziness, and needing to brace himself to get out of bed. Meredith and Derek discuss possible causes, including a brain tumor, but focus on the immediate surgical concerns. Cristina Yang is assigned by Dr. Burke to get a full history from Jorge before surgery, while the team prepares for the complex procedure, weighing the risks of bleeding and infection and emphasizing the importance of removing the nails at the precise angle of entry.

Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens research nail gun injuries to the head, discovering 23 documented cases, most of them accidental, and noting that the primary risks are bleeding and infection. The surgical team—Derek Shepherd, Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, Izzie, Alex Karev, and Dr. Bailey—prepares to operate on Jorge Cruz, who has seven nails embedded in his skull after a fall. With the CT scanner down, they use X-rays and a C-Arm to guide the removal of the nails, emphasizing the need to extract each nail at the exact angle it entered to minimize further damage. Jorge is conscious but blind, and his wife Sona arrives, providing his medical history and revealing he has suffered headaches and dizziness for months. As the team prepares for surgery, Derek feels the pressure of leading the operation and making critical decisions on his own.

In the locker room, Alex Karev teases Izzie Stevens about her past as a lingerie model, calling her "Dr. Model" and referencing her recent appearance in a magazine. Other interns join in, making crude jokes and questioning her professionalism. Izzie, frustrated and humiliated, responds by unbuttoning her scrub top and revealing her tattoos, defiantly showing her body to the group. She asserts that she put herself through medical school with her modeling earnings and demands to be treated as a doctor, not an object. The atmosphere is tense, but Izzie stands her ground, reclaiming her dignity as her colleagues fall silent.

Jorge Cruz lies in his hospital bed as his wife, Sona, sits nearby. They talk about their morning routine, with Sona teasing Jorge about his love for her cheese omelets and his stubbornness. Meredith Grey enters and gently explains that Jorge needs an MRI to check for any residual bleeding in his brain following the nail gun accident. Sona expresses concern, and Meredith reassures them, outlining the next steps in Jorge’s treatment.

Izzie Stevens confronts Mr. Humphrey in his hospital room after learning that he refuses to let her perform his prostate exam, preferring Dr. Bailey or Dr. Victor instead. Izzie stands her ground, firmly telling Mr. Humphrey that she is a qualified physician and demanding to be allowed to do her job. Mr. Humphrey admits he feels uncomfortable because he has seen Izzie’s lingerie modeling photos in a magazine and has fantasized about her, making him embarrassed at the prospect of her witnessing his vulnerability and emasculation during his upcoming prostate surgery. Izzie responds assertively, insisting that her professional skills are what matter and that she deserves to be treated with respect as a doctor, regardless of her past modeling work.

Cristina Yang confronts Dr. Preston Burke about Elizabeth Fallon’s rapidly declining condition, urging him to schedule the Whipple procedure immediately. Burke insists on waiting for the biopsy and overnight lab results before making a decision. Frustrated, Cristina accuses Burke of never intending to operate, suggesting that he is allowing Nurse Fallon to die in the hospital where she spent her career. Burke remains firm in his decision, emphasizing the need for caution, while Cristina’s anger and disappointment grow as she feels the hospital is giving up on Fallon.

Derek Shepherd reviews Jorge Cruz’s imaging and discovers a tumor in the midline of his hypothalamus. Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, Izzie Stevens, Alex Karev, and Shepherd discuss Jorge’s case with his wife, Sona. Shepherd explains the treatment options: surgical removal of the tumor, which could restore Jorge’s vision and give him five to ten more years but carries a high risk of memory loss and personality changes, or focused radiation, which would preserve his identity but likely limit his life expectancy to three to five years. Sona insists the decision is Jorge’s alone, even if it means she will have to remember their life for both of them. Jorge and Sona struggle with the emotional weight of choosing between preserving Jorge’s sense of self and the possibility of a longer life together.

Meredith Grey sits with her mother, Ellis Grey, in the nursing home, showing her old family photographs and gently prompting Ellis to recall memories. Ellis struggles to recognize the people in the photos, her confusion and frustration revealing the effects of early-onset Alzheimer’s. Meredith mentions seeing Elizabeth Fallon, Ellis’s former scrub nurse, at the hospital. Ellis’s demeanor softens as she fondly remembers Fallon, briefly connecting to her past before her memory slips away again.

Meredith Grey confides in Elizabeth Fallon about her mother, Ellis Grey’s, early-onset Alzheimer’s diagnosis, explaining that Ellis is now living in a nursing home and only allows Meredith to visit her. Fallon, surprised to finally meet Ellis’s daughter after years of working with Ellis, comments on Ellis’s formidable reputation and lasting legacy at the hospital, reflecting on the challenges of living up to such a name.

Dr. Preston Burke and Dr. Miranda Bailey discuss whether to proceed with the Whipple procedure for Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, whose condition is rapidly deteriorating due to advanced pancreatic cancer. Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens, frustrated by the lack of intervention, argue that Fallon deserves every possible chance, with Cristina especially insistent that doctors should fight for their patients until the end. Meredith Grey, however, suggests that sometimes aggressive treatment can do more harm than good, questioning whether prolonging life at all costs is always the right choice. Dr. Bailey reveals her suspicion that Dr. Burke never intended to operate, believing Fallon was admitted so she could die in the hospital where she dedicated her career. As Fallon's condition worsens, the team debates the ethics of intervention versus allowing her a dignified death, highlighting the emotional and moral complexities faced by the doctors.

In the locker room, Alex Karev teases Izzie Stevens about her lingerie modeling photos that have appeared in a magazine, making suggestive remarks about her appearance. Meredith Grey and Cristina Yang join in, with Cristina expressing envy and joking that if she looked like Izzie does in the photos, she’d walk around naked all the time. Izzie laughs off the attention, explaining that her looks in the pictures are the result of professional makeup and retouching, not reality. The group continues to banter, with George O'Malley looking uncomfortable as the others discuss Izzie’s modeling past and the unrealistic standards of beauty in the photos.

Miranda Bailey reminds Izzie Stevens of her responsibilities as a surgical intern after Izzie expresses frustration over Mr. Humphrey’s refusal to let her participate in his prostatectomy due to her past as a lingerie model. Bailey firmly tells Izzie that she cannot let personal feelings or embarrassment interfere with patient care, emphasizing that being a doctor means showing up for her patients regardless of how she is treated.

Derek Shepherd explains the risks and benefits of surgery versus focused radiation to Jorge Cruz and his wife, Sona. Removing the brain tumor could give Jorge five to ten more years but may cost him his memory and personality, while radiation would preserve who he is but only offer three to five years. Sona insists the decision is Jorge’s, even if it means she will have to remember their life for both of them. After a difficult conversation, Jorge and Sona decide to proceed with the surgery, accepting the risks together. Meanwhile, Cristina Yang discovers that Nurse Elizabeth Fallon, a former scrub nurse and Cristina’s patient, was never intended to have surgery; instead, the staff admitted her so she could die at the hospital where she worked. Cristina feels betrayed and angry, realizing the staff treats this as a rite of passage for new doctors, and she confronts Dr. Burke and Dr. Bailey about their complicity in the tradition.

Nurse Elizabeth Fallon’s condition rapidly declines as her liver failure worsens. Cristina Yang, frustrated by the lack of intervention, is present at her bedside with Izzie Stevens as Fallon becomes unresponsive. The medical team initiates resuscitation, but Dr. Miranda Bailey reminds them that Nurse Fallon has a do-not-resuscitate order. Cristina hesitates, wanting to keep trying, but Dr. Bailey firmly instructs her to stop. The team stands by in silence as Cristina reluctantly withdraws her efforts, and Nurse Fallon passes away, her time of death quietly called by Dr. Bailey.

Sona Cruz debates with Meredith Grey, Derek Shepherd, and Jorge Cruz about the best treatment for Jorge’s brain tumor. Derek explains that surgery could give Jorge five to ten more years but risks severe memory loss and personality changes, while focused radiation would preserve his identity but only offer three to five years. Sona struggles with the choice, weighing the value of more time against the quality of life, and ultimately supports Jorge’s decision to prioritize his wishes—even if it means caring for him through memory loss. Sona tells Jorge that she will remember for both of them, affirming her commitment to his choice despite the personal cost.

In the operating room, Dr. Victor begins Mr. Humphrey’s prostatectomy with Dr. Miranda Bailey supervising and Izzie Stevens and Cristina Yang assisting. As Dr. Victor prepares to follow his standard procedure, Izzie and Cristina challenge him, insisting that the nerves responsible for sexual function should be spared to preserve Mr. Humphrey’s quality of life. Dr. Victor is dismissive at first, but after persistent advocacy from Izzie and Cristina, he reluctantly allows Izzie to attempt the nerve-sparing technique. Dr. Bailey warns Izzie and Cristina that their actions could have consequences and threatens to report them to Chief Richard Webber, but ultimately stands by their decision, supporting their effort to prioritize the patient’s wishes.

As evening falls, Meredith Grey’s voice narrates a reflection on intimacy, acknowledging its complexity and the absence of clear rules for knowing when boundaries are crossed. At the house, Meredith, George O'Malley, and Izzie Stevens finish their day, exchanging playful banter about household habits and personal space. Meredith warns her roommates not to use her toothbrush, underscoring the blurred lines of living together. The narration continues as Meredith ponders how the rules of intimacy are different for everyone, and that each person must define them for themselves. The scene closes with Meredith quietly wishing her patient good night, highlighting the emotional weight of the day and the ongoing challenge of navigating closeness in both personal and professional relationships.

Late at night at the house, Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, and Izzie Stevens wind down after a long day. As they get ready for bed, Meredith catches George and Izzie reaching for her toothbrush and firmly warns them not to use it, drawing a clear boundary amid their ongoing roommate banter. The atmosphere is quiet and intimate as Meredith narrates, reflecting on how intimacy has no universal rule book and must be defined by each person. The roommates exchange soft goodnights, settling into their separate routines as Meredith’s voiceover lingers on the idea that the rules of closeness are personal and ever-changing.
